notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description:
Programming in a language such as Python. Elementary data types, lists, maps. Program structure: control flow, functions, classes, objects, methods. Algorithms and problem solving. Searching, sorting, and complexity. Unit testing. No prior programming experience required.

NOTE: You may not take this course concurrently with CSC120H1/CSC148H1, but you may take CSC148H1 after CSC108H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Computer Programming

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online course with synchronous and asynchronous components.
Students will work on weekly material in the form of PCRS videos and exercises (asynchronous).
Weekly sessions (3h/week) will be held synchronously to interactively work on practice problems.
Students need the ability to access Blackboard collaborate and the Wing101 IDE.
For more information, please contact ug@cs.toronto.edu

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 30, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Abstract data types and data structures for implementing them. Linked data structures. Encapsulation and information-hiding. Object-oriented programming. Specifications. Analyzing the efficiency of programs. Recursion. This course assumes programming experience as provided by CSC108H1. Students who already have this background may consult the Computer Science Undergraduate Office for advice about skipping CSC108H1. Practical (P) sections consist of supervised work in the computing laboratory. These sections are offered when facilities are available, and attendance is required. NOTE: Students may go to their college to drop down from CSC148H1 to CSC108H1. See above for the drop down deadline.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Computer Science

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please contact ug@cs.toronto.edu

courses.name: Mathematical Expression and Reasoning for Computer Science

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 30, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to abstraction and rigour. Informal introduction to logical notation and reasoning. Understanding, using and developing precise expressions of mathematical ideas, including definitions and theorems. Structuring proofs to improve presentation and comprehension. General problem-solving techniques. Running time analysis of iterative programs. Formal definition of Big-Oh. Diagonalization, the Halting Problem, and some reductions. Unified approaches to programming and theoretical problems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mathematical Expression and Reasoning for Computer Science

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to software design and development concepts, methods, and tools using a statically-typed object-oriented programming language such as Java. Topics from: version control, unit testing, refactoring, object-oriented design and development, design patterns, advanced IDE usage, regular expressions, and reflection. Representation of floating-point numbers and introduction to numerical computation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Software Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1  (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC148H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC148H1 before completing CSC207H1.)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course with synchronous elements (2 hours per week of lectures, online project team meetings, online presentations etc., 2+ hours per week) and asynchronous weekly activities that involve pre-recorded videos, on-line quizzes, and assignments to be submitted online.
There will also be optional synchronous office hours to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and activity content.
The same lecture will be held on Wednesdays from 6-8 pm (ET) and Thursdays 7-9 pm (ET). Students are expected to attend one of these two times, each week.
Students will be expected to have access to q.utoronto.ca and other websites, be able to use Blackboard Collaborate to stream online video lectures, and download and use Java, IntelliJ, and git. Download and instillation instructions will be posted to the Quercus site for this course.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Software techniques in a Unix-style environment, using scripting languages and a machine-oriented programming language (typically C). What goes on in the operating system when programs are executed. Core topics: creating and using software tools, pipes and filters, file processing, shell programming, processes, system calls, signals, basic network programming.
cmCourseInfo.title: Software Tools and Systems Programming

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course with synchronous and asynchronous components.
Students will require internet access suitable for watching Youtube videos, participating in videoconferencing and remote login.
Additional details will be posted on the course website shortly.

courses.name: Introduction to the Theory of Computation

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Synchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: The application of logic and proof techniques to Computer Science. Mathematical induction; correctness proofs for iterative and recursive algorithms; recurrence equations and their solutions; introduction to automata and formal languages. This course assumes university-level experience with proof techniques and algorithmic complexity as provided by CSC165H1. Very strong students who already have this experience (e.g. successful completion of MAT157Y1) may consult the undergraduate office about proceeding directly into CSC236H1 or CSC240H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Theory of Computation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1, 60% or higher in CSC165H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 before completing CSC236H1. Students will not be permitted to retake CSC165H1 after completing CSC236H1.)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. 
Lectures will be given as 2hr /week online videos synchronously (Tuesdays 6-8pm (ET), through Blackboard Collaborate).
Tutorials will be held as  synchronous  1h /week  online webinar (Tuesdays 8-9pm (ET), through Zoom). 
Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous online office hours (Time TBD) to ask questions and clarifications about course content.
Students need PDF viewer and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 30, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Computer structures, machine languages, instruction execution, addressing techniques, and digital representation of data. Computer system organization, memory storage devices, and microprogramming. Block diagram circuit realizations of memory, control and arithmetic functions. There are a number of laboratory periods in which students conduct experiments with digital logic circuits.
cmCourseInfo.title: Computer Organization
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC148H1, 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC165H1/CSC240H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grades in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 are lower than the minimum grades for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC148H1 or CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/​CSC240H1 before completing CSC258H1.)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Monday timeslot is reserved for lab time. For more information, please contact ug@cs.toronto.edu.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Asynchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Algorithm analysis: worst-case, average-case, and amortized complexity. Expected worst-case complexity, randomized quicksort and selection.  Standard abstract data types, such as graphs, dictionaries, priority queues, and disjoint sets. A variety of data structures for implementing these abstract data types, such as balanced search trees, hashing, heaps, and disjoint forests. Design and comparison of data structures. Introduction to lower bounds.
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Structures and Analysis

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
The course will use Blackboard Collaborate, with optional synchronous seminars during posted lecture times.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to agile development methods appropriate for medium-sized teams and rapidly-moving projects. Basic software development infrastructure; requirements elicitation and tracking; estimation and prioritization; teamwork skills; basic UML; design patterns and refactoring; security, discussion of ethical issues, and professional responsibility.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course with asynchronous components.
Additional details regarding the course will be available on the course website shortly.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 9, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to software development on the web. Concepts underlying the development of programs that operate on the web; survey of technological alternatives; greater depth on some technologies. Operational concepts of the internet and the web, static client content, dynamic client content, dynamically served content, n-tiered architectures, web development processes, and security on the web. Assignments involve increasingly more complex web-based programs. Guest lecturers from leading e-commerce firms will describe the architecture and operation of their web sites.
cmCourseInfo.title: Programming on the Web
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and/or tutorials will mostly be run live during the hours listed on the timetable.

courses.name: The Design of Interactive Computational Media

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: User-centred design of interactive systems; methodologies, principles, and metaphors; task analysis. Interdisciplinary design; the role of graphic design, industrial design, and the behavioural sciences. Interactive hardware and software; concepts from computer graphics. Typography, layout, colour, sound, video, gesture, and usability enhancements. Classes of interactive graphical media; direct manipulation systems, extensible systems, rapid prototyping tools. Students work on projects in interdisciplinary teams.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Design of Interactive Computational Media
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: CSC300H1 provides useful background for work in CSC318H1, so if you plan to take CSC300H1 then you should do it before CSC318H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course with asynchronous components. Additional details regarding the course will be available on the course website shortly.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 20, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Programming principles common in modern languages; details of commonly used paradigms. The structure and meaning of code. Scope, control flow, datatypes, and parameter passing. Two non-procedural, non-object-oriented programming paradigms: functional programming (illustrated by languages such as Lisp/Scheme, ML or Haskell) and logic programming (typically illustrated in Prolog).
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Programming Languages
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. 
Lectures and tutorials will be livestreamed at a schedule time(12:10-13:00 ET Wednesdays and Fridays)
Lab sessions (12:10-13:00 ET Mondays) and office hours (times TBD) will also be held virtually. 
Students will require the ability to run Blackboard Collaborate during those hours.
Students will need access to The Racket, Haskell, and Python language interpreters (installation instructions will follow on the course website).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Asynchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of computational methods for solving problems in linear algebra, non-linear equations, and approximation. The aim is to give students a basic understanding of both floating-point arithmetic and the implementation of algorithms used to solve numerical problems, as well as a familiarity with current numerical computing environments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Numerical Methods
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CSC350H1, CSC351H1. NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at FAS, UTM, or UTSC, or the Data Science Specialist at FAS, are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 1-2hr online videos/week asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 3hrs/week (Wednesdays 6-9pm (ET)) to ask questions about the material and to participate in small group active learning.
Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: April 14, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to database management systems. The relational data model. Relational algebra. Querying and updating databases: the query language SQL. Application programming with SQL. Integrity constraints, normal forms, and database design. Elements of database system technology: query processing, transaction management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Databases
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CSC111H1/ CSC165H1/ ​CSC240H1/ ​(MAT135H1, MAT136H1)/ MAT135Y1/ MAT137Y1/ ​MAT157Y1/ (MAT186H1, MAT187H1)/ (MAT194H1, MAT195H1)/ (ESC194H1, ESC195H1); CSC207H1/ ECE345H1/ ESC190H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CSC443H1. NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at FAS, UTM, or UTSC, or the Data Science Specialist at FAS, are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Synchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of operating systems. The operating system as a control program and as a resource allocator. The concept of a process and concurrency problems: synchronization, mutual exclusion, deadlock. Additional topics include memory management, file systems, process scheduling, threads, and protection.
cmCourseInfo.title: Operating Systems
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course with asynchronous components.
Additional details regarding the course will be available on the course website shortly.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Synchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Standard algorithm design techniques: divide-and-conquer, greedy strategies, dynamic programming, linear programming, randomization, network flows, approximation algorithms. Brief introduction to NP-completeness: polynomial time reductions, examples of various NP-complete problems, self-reducibility. Additional topics may include approximation and randomized algorithms. Students will be expected to show good design principles and adequate skills at reasoning about the correctness and complexity of algorithms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Algorithm Design, Analysis & Complexity
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CSC375H1. NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course with asynchronous components.
Additional details regarding the course will be available on the course website shortly.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Synchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Theories and algorithms that capture (or approximate) some of the core elements of computational intelligence. Topics include: search; logical representations and reasoning, classical automated planning, representing and reasoning with uncertainty, learning, decision making (planning) under uncertainty. Assignments provide practical experience, in both theory and programming, of the core topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (CSC263H1/CSC265H1, STA247H1/STA255H1/STA257H1)/Permission of the Cognitive Science Director
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. 
Lectures and tutorials will be given as online lectures between 6-9pm (ET) on Mondays using Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and will be archived for asynchronous review.
Students may be asked to make a short, end of term presentation (using PowerPoint or some comparable tool) and will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 20, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Identification and characterization of the objects manipulated in computer graphics, the operations possible on these objects, efficient algorithms to perform these operations, and interfaces to transform one type of object to another. Display devices, display data structures and procedures, graphical input, object modelling, transformations, illumination models, primary and secondary light effects; graphics packages and systems. Students, individually or in teams, implement graphical algorithms or entire graphics systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Computer Graphics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CSC209H1/proficiency in C or C++, MAT235Y1/MAT237Y1/MAT257Y1, MAT221H1/MAT223H1/MAT240H1. Prerequisite for Engineering students only: ECE345H1 or ECE352H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

Additional details regarding the course will be available on the course website shortly.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 9, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to basic concepts in computer vision. Extraction of image features at multiple scales. Robust estimation of model parameters. Multiview geometry and reconstruction. Image motion estimation and tracking. Object recognition. Topics in scene understanding as time permits.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Image Understanding
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Tuesdays 5 - 6 pm (ET) - office hours, Thursdays 4 - 5 pm (ET) - live lectures) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Students need a PDF viewer, Matlab or Python framework, and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Synchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Course Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Computational linguistics and the processing of language by computer. Topics include: context-free grammars; chart parsing, statistical parsing; semantics and semantic interpretation; ambiguity resolution techniques; reference resolution. Emphasis on statistical learning methods for lexical, syntactic, and semantic knowledge.
cmCourseInfo.title: Computational Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NOTE: Students not enrolled in the Computer Science Major or Specialist program at the UTSG, UTM, or UTSC are limited to a maximum of three 300-/400-level CSC/ECE half-courses.

Slides will be made available after lectures in PDF on the course website, along with assignments and other handouts.

cmCourseInfo.description: This half-course involves a significant project in any area of Computer Science. The project may be undertaken individually or in small groups. The course is offered by arrangement with a Computer Science faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Computer Science Project
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Three 300-/400-level CSC half-courses, and permission of the Associate Chair, Undergraduate Studies. Contact the Computer Science Undergraduate Office for information about course enrolment procedures.

To enrol in this course, please contact the Computer Science Undergraduate Office at ug@cs.toronto.edu.
